nodes.text: Methods and concepts from physics, especially the Ising model and agent-based models, can provide a useful, empirically relevant framework to explain stylized facts of financial markets (fat tails, volatility clustering, bubbles, crashes) and complement or improve upon standard economic equilibrium models

Standard economic models (DSGE, representative agent, efficient markets) assume rational homogeneous agents and equilibrium and therefore fail to capture out-of-equilibrium phenomena such as bubbles, crashes and excess volatility

The Ising model and its generalizations naturally represent competing forces of imitation (social interaction) and idiosyncratic noise, producing collective phenomena, phase transitions, and regime shifts relevant to social and financial systems

Agent-based models (ABMs) and computational economics allow heterogeneous boundedly rational agents and interactions to generate emergent macro-patterns (bubbles, crashes, fat tails) without assuming equilibrium
Extensions of decision theory (random utility/logit as Boltzmann analog, and quantum decision theory) provide formal links between micro decision rules and statistical physics formulations

Empirical puzzles such as the excess volatility puzzle reveal that observed prices fluctuate more than fundamental-value estimates, contradicting implications of optimal forecasting under efficient markets
From a complex systems viewpoint the excess volatility is interpreted as large noise and endogenous market dynamics rather than a paradox invalidating non-equilibrium approaches

Deriving discrete choice with social interaction and limited information leads to a kinetic Ising model (Glauber dynamics) for trader decisions, where imitation strength and idiosyncratic noise determine collective order or disorder

Models with Ising-like imitation produce phenomena seen in markets: transient bubbles via positive feedback, critical-point like susceptibility prior to crashes, volatility clustering and intermittent dynamics

ABMs implementing heterogenous agents, bounded rationality, herding, and strategy adaptation reproduce many stylized facts (fat tails, clustered volatility, trend following, crashes) and can be used to study policy and microstructure

Calibration and validation of ABMs remain open problems due to high dimensionality, nonlinearity, ill-conditioned parameter estimation and limited likelihood tractability, limiting broad adoption by policy makers

Random utility with Gumbel noise yields the logit choice probability which maps to the Boltzmann factor; quantum decision theory generalizes probabilities via interference terms to explain decision anomalies

Quantum decision theory decomposes prospect probability into a utility factor plus an attraction (interference) factor, predicting known paradoxes and allowing quantitative tests against experimental choice data

Empirical applications: log-periodic power law (LPPL) signatures and Ising-type precursor patterns have been used to detect bubbles and produce ex-ante diagnostics via the Financial Crisis Observatory and Financial Bubble Experiment

Practical forecasting and monitoring using physics-inspired diagnostics produced successful ex-ante and ex-post cases (examples include Nikkei and other identified bubbles), indicating some predictive power in bubble regimes
